verses.text: Do not boast about tomorrow, for you do not know what a day may bring.
verses.comment: The verse warns against presumption. Jesus echoes this in Matthew 6:34 and James emphasizes human frailty in planning, suggesting the importance of trusting God's providence and submitting one's plans to Him—themes foundational for a life formed by humility and spiritual discipline.

verses.text: Let another praise you, and not your own mouth; a stranger, and not your own lips.
verses.comment: This verse rebukes self-praise, encouraging humility—virtue later affirmed by Christ (see Luke 14:11). Genuine honor comes from others, especially when accorded by those outside one's household or local community.

verses.text: A stone is heavy, and sand a burden, but a fool's anger is heavier than both.
verses.comment: This proverb uses vivid imagery to illustrate how destructive the wrath of a fool can be. Fools are frequently cautioned against throughout wisdom literature, emphasizing the communal risk of unchecked folly.

verses.text: Wrath is cruel and anger is overwhelming, but who can stand before jealousy?
verses.comment: This contrast highlights jealousy as perhaps the strongest and least manageable of the passions. Scripture frequently warns against envy and jealousy (see Galatians 5:20-21), suggesting a need for the support of a faith community to overcome such temptations.

verses.text: Better is open rebuke than hidden love.
verses.comment: Open correction done in charity is preferable to love that remains concealed and thus fruitless. Brotherhood and accountability in Christian life are essential for growth—see Matt 18:15.

verses.text: Faithful are the wounds of a friend, but deceitful are the kisses of an enemy.
verses.comment: True friends correct each other for their good, even if it hurts. This foreshadows Judas's kiss of betrayal—demonstrating that not all who show outward affection are genuine, and that wise discernment and spiritual companionship are necessary in the Christian walk.

verses.text: A satisfied soul loathes honey, but to a hungry soul even what is bitter tastes sweet.
verses.comment: Spiritual hunger shapes our perception. The verse subtly encourages seeking fulfillment not in worldly things, but in God's Word and sacraments—see John 6:35.

verses.text: Like a bird that strays from its nest is a man who strays from his home.
verses.comment: Straying from one's place brings vulnerability, spiritually and physically. The verse hints at the blessings of stability and order—values the early Church and apostolic tradition upheld in guiding the faithful.

verses.text: Oil and perfume make the heart glad, and the sweetness of a friend comes from heartfelt counsel.
verses.comment: True friendship, like sacred anointing, refreshes and strengthens those who walk together. This points to the goodness of spiritual friendship and direction, later highlighted by Church tradition.

verses.text: Do not forsake your friend or your father's friend; do not go to your brother’s house in the day of your calamity. Better is a neighbor who is near than a brother who is far away.
verses.comment: This imparts the value of faithfulness and community support, even above family at times. The verse subtly affirms the idea of spiritual kinship and communion of the faithful.

verses.text: Be wise, my son, and make my heart glad, so that I may answer anyone who reproaches me.
verses.comment: Wisdom in the life of a believer brings honor to spiritual fathers and wards off opponents—both important in maintaining the integrity of the household of faith.

verses.text: The prudent see danger and take refuge, but the simple keep going and suffer for it.
verses.comment: This proverb, repeated nearly verbatim from 22:3, underscores the necessity of spiritual vigilance—a quality frequently praised in those who persevere in the faith.

verses.text: Take his garment, for he has put up security for a stranger; hold it in pledge when he has done so for an outsider.
verses.comment: This warns against careless financial commitments, especially for strangers, signifying the virtue of prudence and accountability to community standards.

verses.text: If someone blesses his neighbor with a loud voice early in the morning, it will be counted as a curse to him.
verses.comment: This witticism warns about insincere or ill-timed praise. True blessing respects the context and disposition of others, echoing the New Testament exhortations to pray and encourage one another rightly.

verses.text: A continual dripping on a rainy day and a quarrelsome wife are alike;
verses.comment: The proverb uses a vivid image to highlight the weariness caused by constant strife at home. Peace and unity are stressed throughout Scripture as foundational elements of healthy family and spiritual life.

verses.text: restraining her is like restraining the wind or grasping oil in your right hand.
verses.comment: This verse extends the metaphor, emphasizing the futility of trying to control contentiousness through force. It indirectly calls for deeper transformation—such as conversion of heart—over mere external management.

verses.text: Iron sharpens iron, and one man sharpens another.
verses.comment: Authentic Christian fellowship fosters holiness—encouraging accountability, spiritual growth, and perseverance in the faith. The value of spiritual direction and shared life is interwoven in the history of discipleship.

verses.text: Whoever tends a fig tree will eat its fruit, and he who guards his master will be honored.
verses.comment: Faithful service bears fruit both temporally and spiritually. Christ often speaks of stewardship (see Matt 25:21), teaching that diligence in the Lord’s vineyard is rewarded by Him—just as those who care for His house are honored.

verses.text: As water reflects a face, so a man's heart reflects the man.
verses.comment: This proverb affirms the unity of outward action and inward disposition, underscoring the necessity of interior conversion—a recurring emphasis in Christian spiritual teaching.

verses.text: Sheol and Abaddon are never satisfied, and never satisfied are the eyes of man.
verses.comment: The insatiable nature of death parallels human desires left unchecked. This verse subtly reaffirms the teaching on overcoming passions and seeking fulfillment in God rather than in temporary things.

verses.text: The crucible is for silver, and the furnace is for gold, and a man is tested by the praise he receives.
verses.comment: Just as precious metals are refined, so the human heart is tested—especially by praise. Endurance and humility under praise are spiritual virtues, cultivated throughout Christian tradition.

verses.text: Even if you crush a fool in a mortar with a pestle along with grain, his folly will not depart from him.
verses.comment: Some stubbornness is incorrigible by mere force; it takes transformation of the heart—a theme central to Christian conversion and sacramental life.

verses.text: Know well the condition of your flocks, and give careful attention to your herds,
verses.comment: Shepherd imagery foreshadows Christ as the Good Shepherd. Good stewards imitate Him by caring diligently for those entrusted to them, whether in family, ministry, or leadership.

verses.text: for riches do not last forever, nor does a crown endure through all generations.
verses.comment: The ephemeral nature of wealth and power is highlighted, urging a focus on what is eternal rather than what quickly passes—a keystone of Christian teaching on earthly detachment.

verses.text: When the grass is gone and new growth appears, and the herbs of the mountains are gathered in,
verses.comment: This introduces a cycle of seasons and work, inviting reflection on both agricultural reality and the rhythm of spiritual life—echoes of ‘seasons’ in the Church year reinforce this holistic vision.

verses.text: the lambs will provide your clothing, and the goats the price of a field;
verses.comment: Right stewardship provides for material needs, but Scripture always points beyond mere provision to the shepherd’s care—a deeply Christological image in the fullness of Christian teaching.

verses.text: there will be enough goats’ milk for your food, for the food of your household, and nourishment for your servant girls.
verses.comment: Diligent, orderly care results in sufficiency for all under one’s charge, reflecting the call to provide not just for oneself, but for the whole 'household'—a microcosm of the spiritual family.
